sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects Germany's call to boycott British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with German advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists have established whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative on the EU's veterinary committee Werner Zwingmann said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than the UK until the scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we see no basis for it," Commission chief spokesman Nikolaus van der Pas said at a press conference.
He said that further scientific studies are needed and that if it turns out that measures are needed, the European Union should take them.

He said a proposal last month by EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords from the human and animal food chain was a very specific and cautious step to protect human health.
Mr Fischler proposed EU-wide measures following reports from the UK and France that sheep under laboratory conditions can contract bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease.

But Mr Fischler agreed to review his proposal after the EU Standing Veterinary Committee, made up of national animal health officials, questioned whether such measures were justified because there was only a small risk to human health.
Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio had earlier accused Fischler of creating unjustified concern through "dangerous generalisations" at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers.
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's Scientific Veterinary and Interdisciplinary Committees will re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to be infected by scrapie, a brain-damaging disease similar to BSE, which is thought to have been transmitted to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their sheep posed any danger to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"What we have to be very careful about is how other countries will follow Germany's example," John Lloyd Jones, president of the Welsh Farmers' Union (NFU), told BBC radio.

Bonn has led efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March after a British report suggested that people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease from eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of total imports.
It imported 4,275 tonnes of British sheepmeat, representing 10% of total imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare early handwritten draft of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite items on Thursday.
A Florida restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for the draft of "Ain't No Telling," which Hendrix wrote on a letterhead from a London hotel in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in January 1967 in the English city of Nottingham, he threw the paper into the audience, where it was retrieved by an admirer.
The buyers also purchased 16 other items that were auctioned by Hendrix's former girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him between 1966 and 1969.
These include a black lacquer and mother-of-pearl box Hendrix used to store his drugs, which an anonymous Australian buyer bought for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970, aged 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the mood for talks.

China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the mood for a resumption of talks across the Taiwan Strait with a visit to Ukraine by Taiwan's Vice President Lien Chan this week that infuriated Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media said the time was ripe for political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters, "The necessary atmosphere to start the talks has been disturbed by the Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's top negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a visiting group from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for the two sides to start political talks...
That is, to end the hostility," Thursday's foreign edition of People's Daily quoted Tang as saying.

Shen of the Foreign Ministry told Reuters Television in an interview that he had read reports of Tang's comments, but gave no details on why the negotiator felt the time was ripe for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a breakaway province.
China, which has long opposed all Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was furious that Taiwan's Vice President Lien visited Ukraine this week.
China says the time is ripe for talks on Taiwan.
China has said it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps to achieve this goal.

Consultations should be held to determine the time and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, as saying late Wednesday.
German car registrations in July increased by 14.2 per cent this year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
German first registrations of motor vehicles increased by 14.2 percent in July this year compared with last year, the Federal Motor Vehicle Authority announced on Thursday.
According to the office, 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 cars and 15,613 trucks.
The figures represent an increase of 13.6% for passenger cars and a decrease of 2.2% for lorries compared to July 1995.
Motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7 per cent over the period.
The increase was partly due to more Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, according to the federal office.
Almost all German car manufacturers increased their registrations during the period.
Volkswagen AG received 77,719 registrations, slightly more than a quarter of the total.
Opel AG together with General Motors came in second place with 49 269 registrations, 16.4 percent of the total.
In third place was Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7 percent.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 than in July last year.
Seat had 3420 registrations compared to 5522 registrations in July of the previous year.
Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE THE GREEN LIGHT TO THE PRIME MINISTER FOR ELECTIONS.
The Executive Bureau of the Greek Socialist Party gave Prime Minister Costas Simitis the green light to call elections as soon as possible, its Secretary General Costas Skandalidis told journalists.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.

Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appear to be a tempest in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador in Washington conducted fruitless negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that it looked as if Damascus wanted to talk rather than fight.
"It seems that {(1)[MISC] Syria's priority} is still to negotiate.
The Syrians are confused, they're definitely tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovich is finishing his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington on Wednesday, stating that it is committed to peace and wants to start negotiations without preconditions.
But it criticised Damascus for creating what it called a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria accused Israel on Wednesday of launching a hysterical campaign against the country after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
It said its arms purchases were for defensive purposes.

"The message we sent to (Syrian President Hafez al-Assad) is that Israel is ready to start peace negotiations at any time and without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy told Israel Radio in an interview.
Tensions have risen since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June and pledged to keep the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
The Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan have been deadlocked since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices from Damascus are bad, not good.
The media...
are full of expressions and explanations that must be disturbing...
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," says Levy.
"We expect Syria, if it is committed to peace, to respond to Israel's message to start peace negotiations, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
No one benefits from war. "
Israel's Channel Two television channel said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
The source of the report is not specified.
Netanyahu and Levy spokesmen said they could not confirm it.
The TV also said that Netanyahu had sent messages to reassure Syria via Cairo, the US and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies that nurses are stranded in Libya.
A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a Polish tabloid that reported this week that Libya refused exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who tried to return home after working in the North African country.
"That's not true.

So far we have not known of any nurses being stranded or held in Libya without their consent, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, chargé d'affaires at the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's labour ministry said this week it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by complaints from some nurses about their working conditions, such as not being paid their salaries.
He said an estimated 800 Polish nurses are working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq pledged on Thursday to provide support to Iran's Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian troops deep inside Iraq last month.

According to a statement from the Mujahideen Khalq, its leader Massoud Rajavi met with the Secretary General of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI) Hassan Rastegar in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed his support for Iran's Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian Resistance will continue to stand side by side with its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance in Iranian Kurdistan," it says.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between the Mujahideen Khalq and the Kurdish opposition in Iran".
Iran heavily bombed targets in northern Iraq in July in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside Baghdad government control.
Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are controlled by guerrillas from the Iraqi Kurdish group the Kurdish Patriotic Union (PUK).

The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iraq (KDP), the two largest Kurdish factions in Iraq, have been in control of northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two parties erupted over the weekend in the most serious fighting since a US-sponsored ceasefire last year.
Mujahideen Khalq said Iranian troops had also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniya province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
It stated that about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or injured in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey carry out air and land attacks against targets in northern Iraq to fight their own Kurdish rebels.
A US-led air force in southern Turkey protects Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by troops in Baghdad.
The Saudi riyal exchange rate is stable in quiet summer trading.
The Saudi riyal's spot rate against the dollar and the riyal's interbank deposit rates were mainly stable this week in quiet summer trading, according to traders in the Kingdom.
"There were no changes in the Saudi riyal rates.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one trader.
The spot rate was set at 3.7504/06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8 per cent, three months at 5-5/8, 1/2 per cent and six months at 5-3/4, 5/8 per cent.
The one-year funds were at six, 5-7/8 percent.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the PLO, according to an adviser to Arafat.
"The problem is over.
The president's plane has been cleared to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank until Monday, Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was scheduled to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in Ramallah in the West Bank on Thursday, but the meeting was changed to Gaza after Israel denied air permission for the Palestinian leader's helicopters.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on the ground.
Arafat then cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civilian issues at the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat had decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday, after Israel enforced the ban, because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat to meet Peres in Gaza after flight ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians said the Israeli right-wing government has prevented the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japan's Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that he believes the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is aimed at ensuring economic growth, has not changed following the publication of the central bank's think-tank survey.
